DOC.HEAD: Pettersson Demands $320,000 after Acquittal in Palme Murder
DOC.TEXT: Christer Pettersson, a 42-year-old drifter acquitted of the 1986 murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme, wants $320,000 in compensation for the 10 months he was jailed for questioning and trial, news reports said Tuesday. Pettersson, who has a long history of drug abuse and crime, was convicted in July but won an appeal on the grounds of insufficient evidence. He previously said he was not interested in the money. ``This is a lot of money, but it is also a very unusual case,'' the national TT news agency quoted Pettersson's lawyer, Arne Liljeros, as saying. ``Christer Pettersson was detained for a long period, and he has had to suffer much publicity. He is marked for the rest of his life.'' After his release, Pettersson rejected a police offer to relocate him and give him a new identity. Palme, prime minister for 11 years, was shot on a Stockholm street while walking home from a movie with his wife, Lisbeth. Authorities have said Pettersson remains a suspect. He could be tried again under Swedish law, but only on the basis of compelling new evidence.
